div.h2: Splunk Reference App - Pluggable Auditing System (PAS)
div.p: The Pluggable Auditing System (PAS) app and the accompanying guidance will help you learn how to develop apps for Splunk Enterprise. This end-to-end app was developed by a Splunk engineering team in partnership with Conducive Consulting and implements real-world use cases. The presented experience includes software development, testing, packaging and publishing a Splunk app. It is not, however, meant, to cover all technological features of the Splunk development platform.

The app is intended to let an organization monitor various document repositories (current and future). Managers and auditors can use the app to see who has looked at, updated, modified, deleted, or downloaded documents or other artifacts from various sources. By default, the app is configured to use sample data generated on the fly: you may need to wait a few minutes after first installing the app before any data becomes available.

The app includes a number of dashboards that illustrate some of the capabilities of Splunk Enterprise apps written using SimpleXML and the SplunkJS stack. The app is modular in nature and is designed for extensibility. It includes a number of data provider add-ons to simulate other data sources; these add-ons are hidden by default, but you can view them if you navigate to Manage Apps in your Splunk Enterprise installation. It also ships with a real data provider (Google Drive) and a real custom alert action (Atlassian JIRA) - see the corresponding README for instructions on how to enable and configure them. For the app to function, you need to have at least one data provider add-on installed.

On the dashboards, you will see small lightbulb symbols (). If you hover the mouse over any of these you will see some additional information about the panel, and clicking will take you to the relevant location in the guidance.

The Summary dashboard provides an overview of activity in the document repositories highlighting policy violations, suspicious activity, and historical trends. Imagine it to be used in a Command & Control Center. The top two panels only show the data since midnight and refresh automatically every 5 mins.

The User Activity dashboard, that you can navigate to from the list of Top Users on the Summary dashboard (click on the username, choose Drilldown), lets you focus on the activities of a specific user.
The three Suspicious Activity dashboards let you view detailed information about the suspicious activities listed on the Summary dashboard.
The Customer Monitor dashboard lets you monitor accesses to documents in the repository associated with specific customers. Example customers in the sample data include Aladdin, Cade, and Ronan.
The Keycard Activity dashboard lets you track locations and time of the employees access to company resources and real estate. It aggregates the high volume location data into a choropleth map.
The Alerts dashboard lets you set and manage custom alerts triggered by a search.

Finally, there is a Setup dashboard where you are directed the first time you visit the app. On this dashboard you can specify the list of departments to display on the Summary dashboard and customize how the app calculates the policy violation weighted score. This dashboard uses the KV store to persist the settings.
The PAS app makes extensive use of many Splunk knowledge objects that you can view from the Settings menu such as:

ul.li: The PAS Data Model
Custom event types in each of the provider add-ons
Custom tags in each of the provider add-ons
Field aliases, calculated fields, and field extractions in each of the provider add-ons
Lookups in the pas_hr_info app
Custom alert actions

div.p: In addition to the code base, we are making our test resources available for your reference and learning. These include: test automation suites, unit tests and static test data sets. A simulated identity provider is also made available so that you do not need to procure an LDAP/AD server. These additional resources can be accessed through a separate repository on GitHub.

Questions, comments, suggestions? To provide feedback about this release, to get help with any problems, or to stay connected with other developers building on Splunk Enterprise please visit answers.splunk.com community site.

div.p: We strongly value user feedback and appreciate your bug reports/feature requests for future releases. Please use Issues on GitHub to submit them.
You can also contribute to our code base and revise/propose new content for the Splunk Developer Guide. We accept pull requests after you submit your signed contribution agreement.
